item.title: By: Ben Scheirman
item.dc:creator: Ben Scheirman
item.description:
I'd suggest improving the URL-building part of your javascript. Instead of matching the term as part of the route (which can get ugly) it's better to use a query string param.
Something like this:
base_url = "path/to/site?q=" + terms //don't forget to url encode thesee
In addition, the .json extension really isn't required. You can set the contentType of the request to let Rails know to serve up JSON. $.getJSON does this for you.
item.content:encoded:
I’d suggest improving the URL-building part of your javascript. Instead of matching the term as part of the route (which can get ugly) it’s better to use a query string param.

Something like this:

base_url = “path/to/site?q=” + terms //don’t forget to url encode thesee

In addition, the .json extension really isn’t required. You can set the contentType of the request to let Rails know to serve up JSON. $.getJSON does this for you.
